comments.commentBody: It doesn't have to be this way. Just look at the Nordic countries. Strong unions and laws make companies to pay decent wages even for fast food workers. Of course that money is then away from CEOs and share holders. Which is not a bad thing.

This is missing an important truth.  If all Americans were to get more education then the poorly paid groundskeepers and food service workers would simply be more educated.  When a significant proportion of jobs in this country are very low wage, then there will always be working people who are earning very little, regardless of the state of educational achievement in our country.

It's only a matter of time before Wall St and institutional investors demand the reshuffling of Mayer herself. Paying $1.1b for Tumblr is a waste, giving that she has no idea how to integrate and expand it for the benefit of yahoo. She's had the good fortune of an extended honeymoon reprieve from investors due to the alibaba holding, but that would come to pass very soon. If she can't deliver the meat, it won't matter how pretty she dresses herself up and how much lipstick she puts on.

With tax rates so low at the top, there is no incentive for CEOs to share productivity increases with their employees.  With the Fairness Doctrine repealed in the 80s, there is nothing to stop Fox News from broadcasting Republican propaganda 24/7 and calling it news, electing enough Republicans that raising those top tax rates is impossible.  Executives have not become more greedy in the past 35 years than they were in the previous 35.  Now, they get to keep what they take from their employees instead of paying it to the government.
K., if we just hip them enough lawyers to even up the percentage of them between us, India, & China, ther economies will begin to slow immediately.

I watched a story on Ohio education on PBS this evening. It talked about new standards that mandated that all third graders be able to read proficiently in order to be passed on to the fourth grade, then went on to explain that, of course, this would leave way too many students behind, so never mind.

Perhaps out national strategy should be to convince India and China of the importance of being politically correct so they won't continue to pour so much into pushing their best and brightest to out compete us. If we could just get them to spend as much as we do on remedial education....
I am a licensed clinical social worker and I wholeheartedly agree with you

I have a long history of seeing therapists and psychiatrists and I think the whole issue of professional boundaries is a disservice to the client and to therapy in general. I think if the therapist/social worker is mature and non defensive they should be able to read each situation and determine whether self disclosure is of benefit to the client or not.
A blanket rule of professional boundary is a furphy. I would encourage all professional health workers to be themselves in integrity and trust their own instincts. You might be surprised how powerful that can be for you and your clients.

As a psychologist, I was being treated for breast cancer. At the time I chose not to reveal this to most patients. I felt the therapy would get unnecessariy complicated, and frankly, I felt I would get too overburdened if I revealed it, needing to care for myself as well as caring for the patient who would have many feelings stirred up, which I then would have to deal with (esp. since they were introduced by me). I was relatively healthy so I was able, in general, to work well. Also I felt I personally was in a better place if I concentrated on my patients rather than myself.

One or two asked if I was feeling OK, and I told them the truth. But I didn't bring it up my own, and looking back, I don't regret the decision.

A few years later, an old patient returned who had been suffering with some serious medical problems of her own. I was very tempted to reveal that "I could understand" because I had had cancer. Then, out of nowhere, so said: "You know, my mother keeps telling me she understands me because she had breast cancer. I keep feeling really annoyed with that. I don't have cancer, I have something else and, she doesn't understand, no matter what she thinks."

So, as her therapist, I was really glad I kept my boundaries.

As I read comments across various articles related to the reduction of income and benefits of workers in the US (particularly in retail), I find it disturbing that many people are in full support of this reduction of income or the prevention of any increase in the worker's income. Is it because these commentors don't want to see anyone else get an increase in their income due to jealousy, competion, or do they just want the poor to stay poor so that they can remain rich? What's wrong with an increase of income of our workforce to at least continue living with some sort of basic comforts? I find this puzzling and disturbing. Disturbing because it seems like an extremely selfish attitude to prevent someone from gaining any increase in income as the dollar loses value over time. Why don't you want your brother to see an increase in income, at least being able to make it in this life? Rather than being critical and complaining about workers asking for a better life, try adding a constructive suggestion on how they can make it happen.

If all life is sacred, don't eat, John. Anything. Your over-simplistic moral indignation conveniently forgets that even an all plant based diet kills animals. Oh, sure, not Bambi or the cute ones, but plenty of birds, snakes, and ground dwellers. Apparently you do differentiate the value of lives, eh?

And let's not forget that a vegan diet would be impossible if not for modern food distribution, including flying grapes from Chile and shipping fruit and vegetables across the world in refrigerated containers. How's that ozone layer doing for ya?

For those claiming to defend animal rights, first deal with the over 30 million cattle slaughtered in the US each year so you can eat hamburger and steak and wear leather. And the over 3 billion chickens that meet the same fate. Then make a big deal about 2 chimps.

Either all life - human or non-human - is sacred. Or not. Anything else is hypocrisy.

Here is some data about the fate animals meet here in the US:

http://www.humanesociety.org/news/resources/research/stats_slaughter_tot...
You are so wrong on so many levels - "animals do not have rights", "humans are a a unique species" to name but two.  You are obviously using biblical references to support your arguments.

Nobody is saying in the article that apes are human.  On the other hand, humans often bodily harm other humans and that does not turn the agressors into animals.  You can show compassion towards another being without implying, by that, that that being is human or identical to you.  Or is it that we only show compassion for those who are identical to ourselves and we must not show understanding and compassion for those whom be believe "inferiors"?

Yes, so let's imprison and mistreat them all. It's not like we've evolved to the point where we have a choice in our actions and about how we treat other living, sentient, feeling beings. Because it's really all about us, isn't it?

A few isolated cases of what appears to be animal-to-human compassion (as some readers cite) do not make apes into humans. Nine times out of ten a human will be in grave bodily danger in the company of any kind of ape. Not just because they are wild animals, but because we do not have a clue about communicating with them. What we think is a smile is a threat in most of the animal kingdom. Let's not be fooled by furry cuteness... it took millions of years to evolve out of that foolhardy notion and into the survivors that we are today.
Comparing chimpanzees (with DNA very close to ours) to spiders, ants, wasps and moles is a ridiculous and invalid comparison.
Joe understands the article is about chimps.  Talking past his point does not further the cause of these animals' having rights.
Ants do not share 96% of human DNA.  There's plenty of illuminating evidence to be read on the subject of chimp (and others') sentience and intelligence.
I hope those in favor of granting non-humans rights have never intentionally killed a spider, stepped on an ant, blasted a wasp, or poisoned a mole in their garden.

Nobody except yourself is suggesting that chimpanzees should be considered human beings.

The actual (ground-breaking) argument concerns the novel legal concept of sentient persons who are not human beings.
The question is about chimpanzee rights as nonhuman persons - not human rights for chimpanzees.

@Ammo62: "Animals are routinely removed from abusive and neglectful situations, and their abusive owners are frequently brought to court"

If only that were true! Animals are generally regarded as chattel under the law, not sentient beings. In practice it is very difficult to legally get and keep possession of an abused animal(s), and very rarely is a significant penalty imposed on the abuser.

@True Believer: "And God blessed them, and God said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it: and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that moveth upon the earth."

Subdue... Dominion... the OT language of domination is quite clear.

Fascinating.

I missed the word "union" in this analysis. or the words, collective bargainning."

"Employers' bargainning power ....."

Who needs a memory hole or revisionism with Neil Irwin and David Leonhardt on the job lying with statistics?
It's a shame that so many people think the fate of laboratory chimps is a laughing matter.
Actually, no, it doesn't lead there at all.
Please explain this a little more, I'm intrigued.

Dan, I was with you until the last sentence: "But for someone with a sudden and very pressing problem like stress from cancer it's probably more helpful than examining the unconscious."

Not all of psychoanalysis is "examining the unconscious" in some directionless manner; for a cancer patient, it can give them an open-ended opportunity to discuss their cancer experiences as well and any other issue they may want to explore. CBT mght be good, too, but too much emphasis on "cognition" and "behavior" as well as a brief, practical, problem-solving focus may be disrespectful of those patients who want a chance to reflect, examine and perhaps find meaning in their lives. That would, in fact, be a form of what is known as "existential psychoanalysis."
The labor pool has expanded greatly due to immigration.  There are more workers than jobs.  So the wages have fallen as demand has fallen.

If you bothered to read the article, you'd learn that jobs were created. They've just been consistently lower paying jobs over the past 35 years. This has been known for a long time, at least since the 2001 to 2007 faux recovery.

Jorge can't earn more because he has no high school diploma either. He's not really worth much in the job market as his job could easily be done by a teen. The best thing to do is urge him to leave and heavily fine his employer.
With the republicans attacking PlannedParenthood and reproductive rights of women on every level, more unwanted babies are what you are going to get.  Can't blame that one on democrats.
